Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Effect of Intravenous Lignocaine Infusion on Intraoperative Desflurane Requirements

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either a bolus of 1.5 mg/kg of 2% lignocaine hydrochloride followed by an infusion of 1 mg/kg/h (Group A) or an equal volume of normal saline (Group B). Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Participants.evidence: 48 patients aged 18-75 years, scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, or ovarian cystectomy, were randomised

Intervention.evidence: randomised 1:1 to receive either a bolus of 1.5 mg/kg of 2% lignocaine hydrochloride followed by an infusion of 1 mg/kg/h (Group A) or an equal volume of normal saline (Group B).

Objective.evidence: aimed to evaluate the effect of intravenous (IV) lignocaine infusion on the intraoperative end-tidal desflurane (Et-Des) concentration

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Et-Des concentration, measured every 10 minutes until skin closure.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated with allocation concealment using sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and clinicians were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 48 patients aged 18-75 years, scheduled for laparoscopic cholecystectomy, appendicectomy, or ovarian cystectomy, were randomised

Number_Analysed.evidence: Forty-seven patients were analysed (23 in Group A, 24 in Group B) using an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Group A had a significantly lower Et-Des concentration (4.3% ± 0.45%) compared to Group B (5.3% ± 0.56%, p < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: One patient in Group A experienced fast atrial fibrillation postoperatively, which resolved with treatment.
